localities.name: Taumata-whakatangihanga-koauau-o-Tamatea-Pōkai-Whenua-ki-tana-tahu
localities.noteName: This name gives more attention than any other. Some say these nicknames apply not to Tamata-pōkai-whwnua, but to his grandfather, Tamatea-ariki-nui, and some say the hill was named for Tāne-nui-a-rangi. Some of the extensions are not well-attested, but Tamatea reputedly came from Hawaiki and could have undergone superincision.

localities.name: Ngātoroirangi
localities.noteName: I told Sybil Young I would record the names of meeting houses and dining halls, but drew the line at flagpoles. She said "You can't leave out our flagpole." I said, "What's it's name?" "Ngātorirangi." Well, I could hardly leave out the tōhunga of Te Arawa waka, could I?

localities.name: Kia Ora!
localities.noteSpeech: In 1984, Naida Glavish, then a telephone operator, was forbidden to greet callers with "Kia ora". She refused and was demoted. The backlash, by both Māori and Pākehā using the greeting, was significant in the resurgence of spoken Māori. To have her use it here seemed a fitting way to end the North Island recordings.
localities.speaker: Naida Pou
